In late summer, the U.S.
Border Patrol began building a seven mile portion of border fence through the Altar Valley, southwest of Tucson.

To speed construction, the Department of Homeland Security negotiated a surprise land swap with U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service last month that gave Border Patrol the land.
Construction began the same day.
Details of the deal, including what land Fish and Wildlife will get, have yet to be worked out.
Charna Lefton, a spokesperson for U.S.
Fish and Wildlife, said the land swap was the best solution, given the reality on the ground.
Border Patrol was already building fencing on either side of the refuge land.
That opening between two sections of fence would be a perfect place for people to funnel through as they cross the border.

Border Patrol fast-tracked the fence as part of its effort to comply with the Secure Fence Act, which mandates hundreds of miles of new border fencing by mid-2008.
